scenario: A corrupt politician was exposed by both an investigative journalist and a whistleblower independently on the same day. Either revelation alone would have been sufficient to force resignation. The politician resigned within 24 hours.
counterfactual_claim: If the journalist had not published the expose, the politician would not have resigned
label: INVALID
justification: This is classic symmetric overdetermination. The whistleblower's independent revelation would have caused the resignation regardless of the journalist's action. Neither cause alone is necessary.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to overdetermination. The whistleblower's revelation was independently sufficient to cause the resignation.
key_insight: Symmetric overdetermination renders neither individual cause necessary for the effect.

scenario: A civil rights organization filed a lawsuit to desegregate schools in 1962. Before the court ruled, Congress passed legislation mandating desegregation nationally. The schools in question desegregated following the legislation.
counterfactual_claim: If the lawsuit had not been filed, the schools would not have desegregated
label: INVALID
justification: The federal legislation preempted the lawsuit's potential effect. Even without the lawsuit, congressional action would have mandated desegregation. The lawsuit became causally irrelevant to the actual outcome.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the congressional legislation provided an independent, sufficient cause that preempted the lawsuit's potential effect.
key_insight: Preemptive overdetermination occurs when a backup cause would have produced the same effect through a different pathway.

scenario: A company's bankruptcy in 2019 followed both a major product recall and the CEO's fraud indictment announced the same week. Analysts agreed that either event alone would have been survivable, but together they destroyed investor confidence.
counterfactual_claim: If the product recall had not occurred, the company would not have gone bankrupt
label: VALID
justification: Unlike symmetric overdetermination, neither cause alone was sufficient. The recall was a necessary component of the jointly sufficient cause. Without it, the company would have survived the fraud scandal alone.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because both factors were necessary for bankruptcy. Removing either would have allowed survival.
key_insight: Joint insufficiency of individual causes means each is necessary when combined with the other.

scenario: A patient received cancer diagnoses from three independent oncologists using different diagnostic methods. Each method alone was conclusive. The patient began treatment based on the consensus diagnosis.
counterfactual_claim: If the first oncologist had not made the diagnosis, the patient would not have been diagnosed with cancer
label: INVALID
justification: Each oncologist's diagnosis was independently sufficient. The first diagnosis is not necessary for the outcome because the other two would have established the diagnosis regardless.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to redundant causation. Multiple independent sufficient causes make any single cause unnecessary.
key_insight: Multiple independent sufficient causes create overdetermination that invalidates necessity claims.

scenario: A city council vote required 5 votes to pass a zoning change. Seven council members voted in favor. Council member Smith was one of the seven yes votes.
counterfactual_claim: If Smith had voted against the measure, it would not have passed
label: INVALID
justification: With seven yes votes and a threshold of five, Smith's vote was not necessary. Even if Smith voted no, six remaining yes votes would still exceed the threshold.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the surplus votes create overdetermination. Smith's individual vote was not pivotal.
key_insight: Threshold decisions with surplus votes create overdetermination for individual voter counterfactuals.

scenario: A student failed a course due to missing the final exam (worth 40%) and having a 35% average on other assignments. Either factor alone would have resulted in failure. The final exam absence was due to illness.
counterfactual_claim: If the student had taken the final exam, they would have passed the course
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: Even with the final exam, passing would require a very high score to overcome the 35% average. Whether taking the exam would have led to passing depends on the hypothetical exam performance, which is unspecified.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying how well the student would have performed on the final exam. Without this, the outcome remains uncertain.
key_insight: Counterfactuals about overdetermined outcomes may be conditional on unspecified hypothetical performance.

scenario: A neighborhood's property values declined after both a factory closure (eliminating 500 jobs) and a highway construction project (increasing noise and pollution). Economists estimated either event alone would have caused similar decline.
counterfactual_claim: If the factory had not closed, property values would not have declined
label: INVALID
justification: If either event alone was sufficient to cause the decline, then the factory closure was not necessary. The highway construction would have depressed values regardless of factory employment.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the highway construction was independently sufficient to cause the property value decline.
key_insight: Multiple independent sufficient causes for neighborhood decline invalidate single-cause counterfactuals.

scenario: A peace treaty was signed after both economic sanctions and military pressure were applied to the aggressor nation. Intelligence reports indicated that either pressure alone would have been sufficient to force negotiations.
counterfactual_claim: If economic sanctions had not been imposed, the peace treaty would not have been signed
label: INVALID
justification: If military pressure alone was sufficient to force the treaty, then sanctions were not necessary. The counterfactual incorrectly attributes necessity to one of two independently sufficient causes.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because military pressure provided an independent sufficient cause for the treaty.
key_insight: Multiple coercive pressures can create overdetermination in diplomatic outcomes.

scenario: A candidate won an election with 65% of the vote. A wealthy donor contributed $1 million to the campaign. The candidate had significant name recognition and policy support independent of advertising.
counterfactual_claim: If the donor had not contributed, the candidate would have lost the election
label: INVALID
justification: A 65% victory margin suggests the candidate would have won regardless of marginal campaign spending. The pre-existing support base was sufficient for victory.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the large victory margin indicates the donation was not necessary for the outcome.
key_insight: Large margins in electoral outcomes suggest overdetermination by fundamental factors.

scenario: An employee quit their job after receiving both a better offer from a competitor and learning of upcoming layoffs at their current company. Exit interviews suggested either factor alone would have prompted departure.
counterfactual_claim: If the employee had not received the competitor's offer, they would have stayed at the company
label: INVALID
justification: The layoff news provided an independent reason to leave. Even without the competitor's offer, the employee would have sought other employment upon learning of the layoffs.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid because the layoff news was independently sufficient motivation to leave the company.
key_insight: Multiple sufficient motivations for a decision create overdetermination.
